newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Czech fund buys into Bulgaria's Mollovbank.
newsitem.headline: Czech fund buys into Bulgaria's Mollovbank.

text.p: The Czech Investment Fund Istrocapital acquired a $6.25 million stake or 92 percent in Bulgaria's private Mollovbank which was placed in receivership last year, a central bank official said.

"The central bank now has grounds to lift the restrictions imposed on Mollovbank after the Chech fund has transferred $6.5 million to our account in New York," a Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) official, who declined to be named, told Reuters.
Mollovbank, renamed after the acquisition into Eurobank, is expected to boost its capital to 10.7 billion levs from current 800 million levs through a new share issue, the official said.
Last week the BNB decided to take over the powers of Mollovbank's shareholders' meeting for the next three months, which empowered the BNB to decide on its capital raise.

The BNB put Mollovbank in receivership, dismissed its management and appointed sequestrators on September 23 to prevent its insolvency, citing a negative capital-to-assets ratio of 19 percent and outstanding payments of 22 million levs.
On October 31 the BNB filed a bankruptcy suit against Mollovbank, saying the bank's performing assets were not large enough to cover its liabilities.
"The BNB will withdraw the insolvency suit, filed against Mollovbank through the Sofia City Court on grounds of the fresh investment," the BNB official said.
"Lifting receivership restrictions on Mollovbank (Eurobank) is a signal that the BNB is prepared to ease restrictions over other banks, in which investors show serious interest," the official added.
Since last May the BNB has filed insolvency suits against sixteen state and private banks, a third of Bulgaria's banks.

So far only two banks - Madan-based Krystalbank, which stopped operating in November 1995 and the state-owned Mineralbank have been declared bankrupt so far. -- Roumiana Tikholova, Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-84561
